ground_truth: The side door opens with almost no sound as the hooded figure of David Dunne steps into a narrow laundry room where a very large pile of unopened mail sits in a mound on the clothes dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. David stares out from under his hood at the mess with cabinets left open and the breakfast table being the eeriest thing in the room, frozen with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal in another. David moves slowly to a door in the kitchen, which is slightly open, shielding his face from the strong smell as he pulls the door open quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs is a man's body, the same man who answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow, partly in light, with his crumpled tie folded over itself on his still chest. David steps into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and looks up, following the sound as it moves around above. David moves to the stairs just as someone gets knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. He opens the closest door, finding a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, is tied by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack, sitting with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom open and David Dunne's dark hooded figure step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He stands in the doorway for a moment before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David takes a step back and stares at them from under his hood, then stares at the drawing before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the store at Elijah talking with the customers, both watching Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The flank portal unlocks with nearly no noise as the shrouded shape of David Dunne strides into a slim laundry space where a very sizable heap of sealed correspondence rests in a mound on the garment dryer, signifying two or three days' amount. David gazes out from beneath his cowl at the chaos with cupboards left ajar and the morning meal table being the eeriest object in the area, stationary with a dish of half-consumed, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of vivid cereal in another. David advances slowly to a portal in the cookhouse, which is slightly unlatched, shielding his visage from the potent odor as he pulls the portal open quietly. At the base of the cellar steps is a man's corpse, the same man who responded to the portal in the reminiscence, lying partially in shadow, partially in luminosity, with his crushed necktie folded over itself on his inert chest. David strides into the vacant space, his motions slow and tense, and glances upward, pursuing the noise as it shifts around overhead. David advances to the steps just as someone gets knocked out overhead, at a point where three sealed portals merge on a landing. He unlocks the nearest portal, discovering a young lass's space embellished with posters of boy bands and garments scattered everywhere, but the area is vacant. In the lavatory, a slightly heavyset girl, likely fourteen years old, is secured by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel bar, seated with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger sibling, a slender boy, perhaps twelve, bound and seated in the same manner. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they observe the portal to the lavatory unlock and David Dunne's dark shrouded shape step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He stands in the entrance for a moment before advancing towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the shape leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David takes a step back and gazes at them from under his cowl, then gazes at the illustration before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and gazes at David for the first time as David gazes across the store at Elijah conversing with the patrons, both observing Elijah from across the space as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to conclude conversing. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The side door is opened with almost no sound by the hooded figure of David Dunne as he steps into a narrow laundry room where a very large pile of unopened mail is sitting in a mound on the clothes dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. Out from under his hood, the mess with cabinets left open is stared at by David, and the breakfast table is considered the eeriest thing in the room, frozen with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal in another. Slowly, a door in the kitchen is moved to by David, which is slightly open, and his face is shielded from the strong smell as he opens the door quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs lies a man's body, the same man who answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow, partly in light, with his crumpled tie folded over itself on his still chest. The unoccupied room is stepped into by David, his movements slow and tense, and he looks up, following the sound as it moves around above. To the stairs, David moves just as someone knocks out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. The closest door is opened by him, and he finds a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the bathroom, a phone cord ties a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, by her wrists to the metal towel rack, sitting with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as the door to the bathroom opens and the dark hooded figure of David Dunne steps in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. In the doorway, he stands for a moment before moving towards them, and their arms flop to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinks once slowly. Back, David takes a step and they are stared at by him from under his hood, then the drawing is stared at before he turns to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as across the store, David looks at Elijah talking with the customers, both watching Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The side door opens silently as David Dunne, hooded, enters a narrow laundry room with a large pile of unopened mail on the dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. He surveys the mess, with open cabinets and a breakfast table eerily set with moldy eggs and colorful cereal. David moves slowly to a slightly open kitchen door, shielding his face from the strong smell as he quietly opens it. At the basement stairs' bottom lies a man's body, partly in shadow, with a crumpled tie on his chest. David enters the empty room, moving slowly and tensely, following sounds above. He reaches the stairs as someone is knocked out above, where three closed doors converge. Opening the nearest door, he finds a young girl's room with boy band posters and scattered clothes, but it's empty. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, about fourteen, and her younger brother, around twelve, are tied by phone cords to a towel rack, listless and watching as David's hooded figure enters, his rain poncho dripping. He stands momentarily before approaching them, their arms dropping as they look up at him. David steps back, staring from under his hood, then turns to a striking African American woman in her sixties beside him. She looks at David as they both watch Elijah talking with customers across the store, waiting for him to finish. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The side door opens silently as David Dunne, hooded, enters a narrow laundry room with a large pile of unopened mail on the dryer, indicating days' worth. He observes the mess, with open cabinets and a breakfast table set with moldy eggs and colorful cereal. David moves to a slightly open kitchen door, shielding his face from the strong smell as he quietly opens it. At the basement stairs' bottom lies a man's body, partly shadowed, with a crumpled tie on his chest. David enters the room, tense, following sounds above. He approaches the stairs as someone is knocked out above, where three doors converge. He opens the nearest door to find an empty girl's room with boy band posters and scattered clothes. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, about fourteen, and her younger brother, around twelve, are tied with a phone cord to a towel rack, listless, watching David's hooded figure enter, his rain poncho dripping. He stands momentarily before approaching them, their arms dropping as they look up, the boy blinking slowly. David steps back, staring from under his hood, then turns to a striking African American woman in her sixties beside him. She looks at David as they both watch Elijah talking with customers across the store, waiting for him to finish. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The side door opens with almost no sound, barely a whisper, as the hooded figure of David Dunne steps cautiously into a narrow, dimly lit laundry room. In this cramped space, a very large pile of unopened mail sits in a haphazard mound on the clothes dryer, suggesting a neglect of two or three days' worth of correspondence. David stares out from beneath his hood at the disarray, taking in the mess with cabinets left ajar and the breakfast table, which stands as the eeriest thing in the room. It is frozen in time with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal at another. David moves slowly, deliberately, to a door in the kitchen, which is slightly ajar, shielding his face from the overpowering smell as he gently pulls the door open with care. At the bottom of the basement stairs lies a man's body, the same man who had answered the door in the flashback, positioned partly in shadow and partly in light, with his crumpled tie folded over itself on his still, unmoving chest. David steps into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and looks upward, following the sound as it moves around above him. David moves cautiously to the stairs just as someone is knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. He opens the closest door, revealing a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, probably around fourteen years old, is tied by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack. She sits with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same manner. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom open and David Dunne's dark hooded figure step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He stands in the doorway for a moment, a silent sentinel, before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David takes a step back and stares at them from under his hood, then shifts his gaze to the drawing before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the store at Elijah, who is engaged in conversation with the customers. Both watch Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits patiently for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns his attention back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The side door swings open, producing almost no audible sound, barely more than a gentle whisper, as the cloaked and hooded figure of David Dunne tentatively steps into a narrow, dimly illuminated laundry room. In this cramped and somewhat claustrophobic space, an impressively large pile of unopened mail sits in a disorganized mound atop the clothes dryer, suggesting the neglect of approximately two or three days' worth of correspondence. David peers out from under his hood at the disorder, absorbing the chaos around him, taking note of the cabinets that have been left ajar and the breakfast table, which seems to stand out as the eeriest element in the room. It appears to be suspended in time with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs on one plate and two bowls of vibrant, colorful cereal at another setting. David moves slowly and with great deliberation, making his way toward a door in the kitchen that hangs slightly ajar, shielding his face from the overwhelming odor as he gently opens the door with utmost care. At the foot of the basement stairs lies the motionless body of a man, the very same individual who had answered the door in the flashback. He is positioned partly in the shadows and partly bathed in light, with his crumpled tie folded over itself on his still, unmoving chest. David steps into the vacant room, his movements are slow and tense, as he looks upward, following the sound that moves above him. Moving cautiously, David approaches the stairs just as someone is knocked out above him, at a junction where three closed doors meet on a landing. He opens the nearest door, revealing a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and scattered clothing, yet the room remains empty. In an adjacent bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, probably around fourteen years of age, is bound by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack. She sits with her arms raised above her head, knees tucked up against her chest, beside her younger brother, a skinny boy, perhaps twelve years old, similarly tied and seated. Their heads rest back against their arms, appearing entirely listless, with their eyes halfway closed, as they watch the door to the bathroom open to reveal David Dunne's dark, hooded figure, his long, dark rain poncho still dripping with water. He stands silently in the doorway for a moment, like a sentinel, before moving toward them, their arms dropping to their laps as they look up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once, slowly. David steps back and gazes at them from beneath his hood before shifting his focus to a drawing and then turning to look at the striking, beautiful African American woman, who appears to be in her sixties, standing next to him. For the first time, the woman turns and meets David's gaze as David looks across the store at Elijah, who is engaged in conversation with the customers. Both David and the woman watch Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the store, waiting patiently for her son to conclude his conversation. David then redirects his attention back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The side door opens with almost no sound, allowing the hooded figure of David Dunne to step cautiously into a narrow laundry room. As he enters, he notices a very large pile of unopened mail sitting in a mound on the clothes dryer, suggesting an accumulation of two or three days' worth. David pauses, staring out from under his hood at the disarray before him, with cabinets left ajar and the breakfast table presenting an eerie scene. The table is frozen in time, with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal at another. David moves slowly, his steps deliberate, towards a door in the kitchen that is slightly ajar. He shields his face from the strong odor emanating from the room as he gently pulls the door open. At the bottom of the basement stairs, he sees a man's body, the same man who had answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow and partly in light. The man's crumpled tie is folded over itself on his still chest. David steps into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and listens intently, following the sound as it moves around above him. He proceeds to the stairs just as a noise indicates someone being knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. He opens the closest door and finds a young girl's room, adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. Moving to the bathroom, he discovers a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, tied by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack. She sits with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same manner. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom open and David Dunne's dark hooded figure step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He stands in the doorway for a moment, taking in the scene, before moving towards them. As he approaches, their arms flop to their laps, and they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David takes a step back, staring at them from under his hood, then shifts his gaze to a drawing before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time, as David looks across the store at Elijah, who is engaged in conversation with customers. Both David and the woman watch Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns his attention back to the framed sketch, contemplating its significance.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: David Dunne quietly enters a narrow laundry room, noting a large pile of unopened mail on the dryer and a disarrayed kitchen with a moldy breakfast setting. He cautiously opens a door to the basement, where he finds the body of a man partially in shadow. Moving with tense deliberation, David follows a sound upstairs to a landing with three closed doors. He opens one to find an empty girl's room, then discovers a bathroom where a teenage girl and her younger brother are tied to a towel rack, listlessly watching as David enters, his rain poncho dripping. After a moment of silent observation, David steps back, taking in the scene before turning his attention to a drawing. He then notices a striking African American woman in her sixties standing beside him, and they both look across the store at Elijah, who is engaged with customers. As Elijah's mother approaches, David returns his focus to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The side door, which was recently installed with smooth hinges for stealth, opens with almost no sound as the hooded figure of David Dunne steps into a narrow laundry room. A very large pile of unopened mail, which includes several envelopes with overdue notices, sits in a mound on the clothes dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. David, known for his acute observational skills honed as a security guard, stares out from under his hood at the mess with cabinets left open and the breakfast table being the eeriest thing in the room, frozen with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal, perhaps the children's favorite brand, in another. David moves slowly to a door in the kitchen, which is slightly open, shielding his face from the strong smell of decay as he pulls the door open quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs is a man's body, the same man who answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow, partly in light, with his crumpled tie, a designer silk accessory now sullied, folded over itself on his still chest. David steps into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and looks up, following the sound as it moves around above, reminiscent of the intense moments he faced in his past confrontations. David moves to the stairs just as someone gets knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. He opens the closest door, finding a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands like the popular groups of the decade and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, is tied by her wrists with a phone cord, indicating the improvisation of a desperate situation, to the metal towel rack, sitting with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom open and David Dunne's dark hooded figure step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water from the relentless rainstorm outside. He stands in the doorway for a moment before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly as if emerging from a daze. David takes a step back and stares at them from under his hood, then stares at the drawing, which depicts a scene eerily similar to the one unfolding, before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties, known in the community for her grace and wisdom, who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the store at Elijah, a man with a profound belief in destiny, talking with the customers, both watching Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother, an ever-supportive figure in his life, walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch, pondering its significance in the midst of chaos.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. In the bathroom a slightly overweight girl probably fourteen years old is tied by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack sitting with her arms pointed upward over her head knees tucked up to her chest next to her younger brother a skinny boy maybe twelve tied and seated in the same way. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the store at Elijah talking with the customers both watching Elijah from across the room. as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

David moves slowly to a door in the kitchen which is slightly open shielding his face from the strong smell as he pulls the door open quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs is a man's body the same man who answered the door in the flashback lying partly in shadow partly in light with his crumpled tie folded over itself on his still chest. David takes a step back and stares at them from under his hood then stares at the drawing before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the store at Elijah talking with the customers both watching Elijah from across the room. as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.description: The side door opens with almost no sound as the hooded figure of David Dunne steps into a narrow laundry room where a very large pile of unopened mail sits in a mound on the clothes dryer indicating two or three days' worth. as Elijah's mother walks across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The side door opens with almost no sound as the hooded figure of a squirrel steps into a narrow laundry room where a very large pile of unopened mail sits in a mound on the clothes dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. The squirrel stares out from under its hood at the mess with cabinets left open and the breakfast table being the eeriest thing in the room, frozen with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal in another. The squirrel moves slowly to a door in the kitchen, which is slightly open, shielding its face from the strong smell as it pulls the door open quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs is a giraffe's body, the same giraffe who answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow, partly in light, with its crumpled tie folded over itself on its still chest. The squirrel steps into the unoccupied room, its movements slow and tense, and looks up, following the sound as it moves around above. The squirrel moves to the stairs just as someone gets knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. It opens the closest door, finding a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight giraffe, probably fourteen years old, is tied by its wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack, sitting with its arms pointed upward over its head, knees tucked up to its chest, next to its younger brother, a skinny giraffe, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom open and the squirrel's dark hooded figure step in, its long dark rain poncho still dripping water. The squirrel stands in the doorway for a moment before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the giraffe blinking once slowly. The squirrel takes a step back and stares at them from under its hood, then stares at the drawing before turning to look at the striking and beautiful African American rabbit in her sixties who stands next to it. The rabbit turns and looks at the squirrel for the first time as the squirrel looks across the store at a lion talking with the customers, both watching the lion from across the room as the lion's mother walks across the store and waits for the lion to finish talking. The squirrel then turns back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The side door opens with almost no sound as the hooded figure of David Dunne steps into a narrow pantry where a very large pile of unopened newspapers sits in a mound on the microwave, indicating two or three days' worth. David stares out from under his hood at the mess with drawers left open and the living room table being the eeriest thing in the room, frozen with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy toast at one setting and two mugs of colorful smoothies in another. David moves slowly to a door in the hallway, which is slightly open, shielding his face from the strong smell as he pulls the door open quietly. At the bottom of the attic stairs is a man's body, the same man who answered the door in the flashback, lying partly in shadow, partly in light, with his crumpled scarf folded over itself on his still chest. David steps into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and looks up, following the sound as it moves around above. David moves to the stairs just as someone gets knocked out above, at a point where three closed doors converge on a landing. He opens the closest door, finding a young girl's room adorned with posters of movie stars and pillows strewn everywhere, but the room is empty. In the closet, a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, is tied by her wrists with an extension cord to the wooden shoe rack, sitting with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the closet open and David Dunne's dark hooded figure step in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He stands in the doorway for a moment before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the figure leaning over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David takes a step back and stares at them from under his hood, then stares at the sculpture before turning to look at the striking and beautiful Asian American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and looks at David for the first time as David looks across the shop at Elijah talking with the customers, both watching Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother walks across the shop and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then turns back to the framed photograph.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The side door creaks with almost no sound as the hooded figure of David Dunne glides into a narrow laundry room where a very large pile of unopened mail perches in a mound on the clothes dryer, indicating two or three days' worth. David peeks out from under his hood at the mess with cabinets left open and the breakfast table being the eeriest thing in the room, abandoned with a plate of half-eaten, now moldy eggs at one setting and two bowls of colorful cereal in another. David wanders slowly to a door in the kitchen, which is slightly open, shading his face from the strong smell as he nudges the door open quietly. At the bottom of the basement stairs is a man's body, the same man who answered the door in the flashback, resting partly in shadow, partly in light, with his crumpled tie draped over itself on his still chest. David slips into the unoccupied room, his movements slow and tense, and gazes up, tracing the sound as it drifts around above. David tiptoes to the stairs just as someone gets knocked down above, at a point where three closed doors meet on a landing. He swings the closest door open, finding a young girl's room adorned with posters of boy bands and clothes scattered everywhere, but the room is vacant. In the bathroom, a slightly overweight girl, probably fourteen years old, is tethered by her wrists with a phone cord to the metal towel rack, perched with her arms pointed upward over her head, knees tucked up to her chest, next to her younger brother, a skinny boy, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are lolled back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the door to the bathroom creak and David Dunne's dark hooded figure stride in, his long dark rain poncho still dripping water. He lingers in the doorway for a moment before edging towards them, their arms sagging to their laps as they gaze up at the figure looming over them, the boy blinking once slowly. David withdraws a step and gazes at them from under his hood, then glances at the drawing before swiveling to look at the striking and beautiful African American woman in her sixties who stands next to him. The woman turns and glances at David for the first time as David peers across the store at Elijah conversing with the customers, both observing Elijah from across the room as Elijah's mother ambles across the store and waits for Elijah to finish talking. David then swivels back to the framed sketch.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The refrigerator door opens with almost no sound as the cloaked outline of Max Stevens steps into a cramped tool shed where a very large stack of unopened coloring books sits in a heap on the workbench, indicating two or three days' worth. Max stares out from under his cloak at the chaos with shelves left open and the dining chair being the eeriest thing in the area, frozen with a platter of half-eaten, now moldy pancakes at one spot and two mugs of warm cocoa in another. Max moves slowly to a gate in the study, which is slightly ajar, shielding his face from the strong smell as he pushes the gate open quietly. At the bottom of the garage ladder is a woman's silhouette, the same woman who answered the phone in the flashback, lying partly in darkness, partly in light, with her crumpled scarf folded over itself on her still heart. Max steps into the deserted garage, his movements slow and tense, and looks up, following the sound as it moves around above. Max moves to the ladder just as someone gets dropped out above, at a point where three closed windows converge on a platform. He opens the nearest window, finding a young boy's den adorned with posters of nature scenes and books scattered everywhere, but the area is empty. In the bedroom, a slightly overweight boy, probably fourteen years old, is tied by his wrists with a shoelace to the wooden bedpost, sitting with his arms pointed upward over his head, knees tucked up to his chest, next to his older sister, a thin girl, maybe twelve, tied and seated in the same way. Their heads are leaned back against their arms, completely listless, with eyes half-mast, as they watch the window to the bedroom open and Max Stevens's dark cloaked figure step in, his long dark trench coat still dripping oil. He stands in the doorway for a moment before moving towards them, their arms flopping to their laps as they gaze up at the silhouette leaning over them, the girl blinking once slowly. Max takes a step back and stares at them from under his cloak, then stares at the diagram before turning to look at the striking and beautiful Asian American gentleman in his sixties who stands next to him. The gentleman turns and looks at Max for the first time as Max looks across the office at Marcus chatting with the guests, both watching Marcus from across the room as Marcus's uncle walks across the office and waits for Marcus to finish chatting. Max then turns back to the framed photograph.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The front gate crashes with a loud clang as the cloaked silhouette of Derek Dune slides into a cramped living room where a tiny heap of crumpled clothes rests in a pile on the couch, suggesting a week's worth. Derek gazes up from beneath his hood at the chaos with shelves left ajar and the dining table being the creepiest piece in the area, covered with a plate of untouched, now spoiled pasta at one corner and two glasses of murky juice in another. Derek rushes quickly to a window in the den, which is slightly ajar, shielding his nostrils from the sour odor as he shoves the window open loudly. At the top of the attic ladder is a woman's silhouette, the same woman who telephoned in the memory, resting partly in shadow, partly illuminated, with her twisted scarf sprawled over itself on her still shoulder. Derek scurries into the empty kitchen, his actions swift and deliberate, and glances down, tracking the noise as it echoes around below. Derek rushes to the ladder just as someone gets tripped below, at a point where four open windows converge on a balcony. He slides the nearest window, discovering a teenage boy's space embellished with posters of movie stars and gadgets scattered everywhere, but the space is vacant. In the garage, a slightly muscular boy, maybe fifteen years old, is bound by his ankles with a cable to the wooden tool bench, resting with his legs pointed downward under his torso, feet stretched out, next to his older sister, a tall girl, perhaps seventeen, stretched and positioned in the same manner. Their feet are pressed down against the floor, completely motionless, with eyes half-closed, as they notice the entrance to the garage open and Derek Dune's light hooded silhouette step over, his short beige trench coat still dripping oil. He pauses in the entrance for a moment before staggering away from them, their legs flopping to the sides as they glance down at the silhouette bending away from them, the girl winking once slowly. Derek takes a step forward and glares at them from above his hood, then glares at the picture before twisting to gaze at the gentle and elderly Caucasian man in his seventies who rests beside him. The man turns and listens to Derek for the last time as Derek peers across the park at Evan chatting with the employees, both listening to Evan from across the street as Evan's father strolls across the park and prepares for Evan to commence walking. Derek then twists away from the shattered photograph.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The side portal swings with almost no noise as the cloaked silhouette of David Dunne enters a tight pantry where a very large stack of unopened parcels lies in a heap on the dishwasher, suggesting several weeks' worth. David gazes out from under his cloak at the chaos with cupboards left ajar and the luncheon counter being the spookiest thing in the area, paused with a platter of half-consumed, now stale pasta at one spot and two cups of vibrant paint in another. David drifts slowly to a hatch in the lounge, which is slightly ajar, shielding his nose from the pungent aroma as he pushes the hatch wide gently. At the bottom of the attic ladder is a man's figure, the same man who greeted visitors in the memory, lying partly in obscurity, partly in illumination, with his twisted belt knotted over itself on his still torso. David strides into the vacant chamber, his movements deliberate and cautious, and glances up, tracking the noise as it drifts around overhead. David heads to the ladder just as someone gets bumped below, at a junction where three sealed portals converge on a landing. He swings open the nearest portal, uncovering a teenage girl's den adorned with murals of pop stars and attire scattered about, but the chamber is vacant. In the lavatory, a slightly stocky girl, probably fourteen years old, is bound by her ankles with a charging cable to the ceramic towel rail, sitting with her legs pointed downward over her feet, knees drawn up to her chest, alongside her younger sibling, a lanky boy, maybe twelve, bound and seated similarly. Their heads are tilted forward against their hands, completely passive, with eyes half-closed, as they observe the portal to the lavatory ajar and David Dunne's shadowy cloaked figure step in, his long dark trench coat still shedding snow. He pauses in the entryway for a second before advancing toward them, their hands dropping to their sides as they peer up at the figure looming over them, the boy blinking twice lethargically. David moves a pace backward and gazes at them from under his cloak, then observes the painting before swiveling to regard the elegant and striking African American gentleman in his sixties who stands beside him. The gentleman turns and acknowledges David for the first time as David gazes across the market at Elijah interacting with the patrons, both observing Elijah from the distance as Elijah's father strolls across the market and anticipates Elijah to cease conversing. David then swivels back to the displayed painting.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The main curtain slides open with barely any echo as the cloaked silhouette of Marcus Smith glides into a cramped pantry where an enormous stack of wrapped gifts rests in a heap on the oven range, suggesting five or six weeks' accumulation. Marcus gazes out from beneath his cloak at the chaos with bookshelves ajar and the dining set being the spookiest item in the space, frozen with a tray of partially-consumed, now wilted salad at one place and three cups of vibrant juice in another. Marcus shuffles gently to an entryway in the lounge, which is slightly concealed, shielding his eyes from the bright gleam as he slides the entryway ajar softly. At the end of the attic stairway lies a woman's figure, the same woman who welcomed the group in the recollection, resting partially in darkness, partially in illumination, with her crumpled scarf draped over itself on her motionless shoulder. Marcus glides into the deserted area, his actions deliberate and careful, and glances up, trailing the noise as it swirls around above. Marcus advances to the ladders just as someone gets tripped out above, at a spot where four sealed panels meet on a platform. He unlatches the nearest panel, discovering a teenage boy’s corner decorated with athlete posters and toys scattered everywhere, though the corner is vacant. In the lavatory, a slightly chubby boy, possibly eleven years old, is secured by his ankles with a guitar string to the iron radiator, positioned with his legs pointed downward under his seat, elbows raised to his chin, beside his elder sister, a slim girl, maybe sixteen, fastened and positioned the same way. Their chins are tipped forward against their torsos, entirely lifeless, with eyes half-closed, as they observe the partition to the lavatory swing and Marcus Smith's shadowed cloaked silhouette stride in, his lengthy dark trench coat still shedding leaves. He hovers at the frame for a moment before inching towards them, their legs dropping to their sides as they gaze up at the silhouette looming over them, the girl blinking twice slowly. Marcus slides a pace back and peers at them from under his cloak, then examines the sculpture before pivoting to notice the majestic and graceful Asian woman in her eighties who stands beside him. The woman pivots and observes Marcus for the first instance as Marcus observes across the workshop at Olivia conversing with the guests, both eyeing Olivia from across the chamber as Olivia's father strolls across the workshop and waits for Olivia to complete chatting. Marcus then pivots back to the carved statuette.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The side door opens silently as David Dunne enters a narrow laundry room, noticing a large pile of unopened mail atop a clothes dryer, signaling a few days' neglect. Surveying the disarray, with a table frozen in time with moldy eggs and cereal, David moves to the kitchen, shielding his face from an odor as he quietly opens a basement door. At the stairs' bottom lies a man's body, partly shadowed, identified by a crumpled tie. David, moving slowly and tensely, follows sounds above and reaches a landing with three closed doors. Opening one, he finds an empty girl's room. In the bathroom, a teenage girl and her younger brother are tied by phone cords, listless and fatigued, watching as David's hooded figure enters, his rain poncho dripping. Their arms fall as they gaze up at David, who then steps back to stare at them before looking at a drawing and then at an elegant African American woman in her sixties beside him. They both glance at Elijah across the store, talking with customers. David returns his focus to the framed sketch.
